subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
msgSnippet: Since I already mentioned Aspect Oriented Programming, I guess a way to test private methods would be using Priviledged Aspects in AspectJ, but I don t think
messageBody:
Since I already mentioned Aspect Oriented Programming, I guess a way to test private methods would be using "Priviledged Aspects" in AspectJ, but I don't think it's viable reply for an urgent situation. I am not using aspects in productions, just experimenting at the moment...

...
Leaving important information to comments, docs etc is extremely dangerous! I suggest you check out refactoring > cataloguewww.refactoring.com ("Comments lie, code does not") and how refactoring community treats comments: either you don't need them so you eliminate them or you make code out of them. Similar thing goes for documentation that is trying to explain code.
Making testing influence your design decision is an example of very testing-biased paradigm, but this should not conflict with basic premises of OO, like most of new usefull paradigms don't (for example AOP does not make you change OO principles, it builds on them).
